001package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful;
002
003import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.SpriteBatch;
004import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.glutils.ShaderProgram;
005import com.badlogic.gdx.utils.GdxRuntimeException;
006import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorfulBatch;
007import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorfulSprite;
008
009/**
010 * Shader code to construct a {@link ShaderProgram} that can render the specialized colors produced by the rest of this
011 * library. The shader code is meant for use in a {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.SpriteBatch}; a convenience
012 * method, {@link #makeBatch()}, is provided to generate and return a SpriteBatch that uses a correct ShaderProgram.
013 * Many of the shaders here are experimental and meant as a basis for user code, rather than a complete solution.
014 * If you aren't familiar with shaders in libGDX, <a href="https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/wiki/Shaders">see this
015 * libGDX wiki article</a> for more information.
016 * <br>
017 * None of the shaders here specify a {@code #version}, and some combinations of OS, driver, and GPU hardware may
018 * require the version to be set to a specific value. You may need to put:
019 * {@code ShaderProgram.prependVertexCode = "#version 110\n";
020 * ShaderProgram.prependFragmentCode = "#version 110\n";} in your launchers, with whatever version you can support, in
021 * order to avoid some warnings or errors on some systems.
022 * <br>
023 * Many of these shaders would need at least some changing to work with kinds of
024 * {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch} that aren't SpriteBatch (or at least very similar). You should compare
025 * the names of {@code uniform} variables in the vertex and fragment shader if you use a different kind of Batch; if all
026 * of them are the same and there are the same amount, then you should be able to use these shaders without issue.
027 * <br>
028 * Note that you don't need to specify a shader from here at all if you use a ColorfulBatch from this library!
029 * There is a ColorfulBatch in each of the color space subpackages, such as {@code rgb}, {@code oklab}, and {@code ipt}.
030 * All of those allow a multiplicative "tweak" to each color channel before an additive change is applied to that
031 * channel; to contrast, all of the shaders here can only permit one or the other for a given channel. ColorfulBatch may
032 * act oddly if it has to interact with SpriteBatch-specific classes like {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Sprite},
033 * so there are ColorfulSprite classes that also allow setting the "tweak" and additive change per-sprite. Still, it can
034 * be a good idea to use the shaders here if you have an existing SpriteBatch, or want to use the various experimental
035 * shaders as a test-bed.
036 */
037public class Shaders {
038    /**
039     * This is the default vertex shader from libGDX. It is used without change by most of the fragment shaders here.
040     */
041    public static final String vertexShader = "attribute vec4 " + ShaderProgram.POSITION_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
042            + "attribute vec4 " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
043            + "attribute vec2 " + ShaderProgram.TEXCOORD_ATTRIBUTE + "0;\n"
044            + "uniform mat4 u_projTrans;\n"
045            + "varying vec4 v_color;\n"
046            + "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n"
047            + "\n"
048            + "void main()\n"
049            + "{\n"
050            + "   v_color = " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
051            + "   v_color.a = v_color.a * (255.0/254.0);\n"
052            + "   v_texCoords = " + ShaderProgram.TEXCOORD_ATTRIBUTE + "0;\n"
053            + "   gl_Position =  u_projTrans * " + ShaderProgram.POSITION_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
054            + "}\n";
055    /**
056     * A simple shader that uses additive blending with "normal" RGBA colors (alpha is still multiplicative).
057     * With the default SpriteBatch ShaderProgram, white is the neutral color, 50% gray darkens a color by about 50%,
058     * and black darkens a color to black, but nothing can brighten a color. With this, 50% gray is the neutral color,
059     * white adds 0.5 to the RGB channels (brightening it and also desaturating it), and black subtracts 0.5 from the
060     * RGB channels (darkening and desaturating, but not to black unless the color is already somewhat dark). When
061     * tinting with white, this looks like <a href="https://i.imgur.com/iAb1rig.png">The Mona Lisa on the left</a>, when
062     * tinting with 50% gray, it makes no change, and when tinting with black, it almost reaches all black, but some
063     * faint part of the image is still barely visible.
064     * <br>
065     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
066     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
067     * <br>
068     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
069     */
070    public static final String fragmentShaderRGBA =
071            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
072                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
073                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
074                    "#else\n" +
075                    "#define LOWP \n" +
076                    "#endif\n" +
077                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
078                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
079                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
080                    "void main()\n" +
081                    "{\n" +
082                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
083                    "   gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(tgt.rgb * pow((v_color.rgb + 0.1) * 1.666, vec3(1.5)), v_color.a * tgt.a), 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
084                    "}";
085    /**
086     * A simple shader that uses multiplicative blending with "normal" RGBA colors, and is simpler than
087     * {@link #fragmentShaderRGBA} but can make changes in color smoother. With the default SpriteBatch ShaderProgram,
088     * white is the neutral color, 50% gray darkens a color by about 50%, and black darkens a color to black, but
089     * nothing can brighten a color. With this, 50% gray is the neutral color, white multiplies the RGB channels by
090     * 2.0 (brightening it and slightly desaturating it), and black multiplies the RGB channels by 0 (reducing the color
091     * always to black). When tinting with white, this looks like <a href="https://i.imgur.com/I30jeXv.png">The Mona
092     * Lisa on the left</a>; when tinting with 50% gray, it makes no change, and when tinting with black, it produces an
093     * all-black image.
094     * <br>
095     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
096     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
097     * <br>
098     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
099     * <br>
100     * An earlier version of this attempted to use some useful code by CypherCove in gdx-tween, but the current version
101     * doesn't share any code, and doesn't really do any gamma correction either. It does less... gamma... un-correction
102     * than {@link #fragmentShaderRGBA}, though, so if the source images are gamma-corrected this should be fine.
103     */
104    public static final String fragmentShaderGammaRGBA =
105            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
106                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
107                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
108                    "#else\n" +
109                    "#define LOWP \n" +
110                    "#endif\n" +
111                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
112                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
113                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
114                    "void main()\n" +
115                    "{\n" +
116                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D(u_texture, v_texCoords);\n" +
117                    "   gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(tgt.rgb * v_color.rgb * 2.0, v_color.a * tgt.a), 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
118                    "}";
119    //// save the result as shader, and set it on your batch with
120    // ShaderProgram shader = makeRGBAShader();
121    // batch.setShader(shader)
122    /**
123     * A simple helper method that builds the simplest shader here; this shader allows tinting with light colors to
124     * lighten an image. You can assign the result to a SpriteBatch with its
125     * {@link SpriteBatch#setShader(ShaderProgram)} method.
126     * <br>
127     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
128     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
129     * @return a ShaderProgram that uses the RGBA shader {@link #fragmentShaderRGBA}
130     */
131    public static ShaderProgram makeRGBAShader()
132    {
133        ShaderProgram shader = new ShaderProgram(vertexShader, fragmentShaderRGBA);
134        if(!shader.isCompiled())
135            throw new GdxRuntimeException("Couldn't compile shader: " + shader.getLog());
136        return shader;
137    }
138    /**
139     * A simple helper method that builds the simplest shader here; this shader allows tinting with light colors to
140     * lighten an image, and also smooths changes well. You can assign the result to a SpriteBatch with its
141     * {@link SpriteBatch#setShader(ShaderProgram)} method.
142     * <br>
143     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
144     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
145     * @return a ShaderProgram that uses the RGBA shader {@link #fragmentShaderGammaRGBA}
146     */
147    public static ShaderProgram makeGammaRGBAShader()
148    {
149        ShaderProgram shader = new ShaderProgram(vertexShader, fragmentShaderGammaRGBA);
150        if(!shader.isCompiled())
151            throw new GdxRuntimeException("Couldn't compile shader: " + shader.getLog());
152        return shader;
153    }
154
155    /**
156     * Where the magic happens; this converts a batch color from the YCwCm format (used by colorful's ycwcm package) to
157     * RGBA. The vertex color will be split up into 4 channels just as a normal shader does, but the channels here are
158     * luma, chromatic warmth, chromatic mildness, and alpha; alpha acts just like a typical RGBA shader, but the others
159     * are additive instead of multiplicative, with 0.5 as a neutral value. This does not support the "tweak" features
160     * that {@link ColorfulBatch} does, which include multiplicative counterparts to the additive operations this
161     * supports on luma, chromatic warmth, and chromatic mildness, plus a contrast adjustment. If you want to adjust
162     * contrast globally, you can use {@link #makeBatch(float)} to set the contrast for a new Batch with a new shader.
163     * <br>
164     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
165     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
166     * <br>
167     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
168     */
169    public static final String fragmentShader =
170            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
171                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
172                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
173                    "#else\n" +
174                    "#define LOWP \n" +
175                    "#endif\n" +
176                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
177                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
178                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
179                    "const vec3 bright = vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125);\n" +
180                    "void main()\n" +
181                    "{\n" +
182                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
183                    "////use the following line to match the color exactly\n" +
184                    "   vec3 ycc = vec3(v_color.r - 0.5 + dot(tgt.rgb, bright), ((v_color.g - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.r - tgt.b), ((v_color.b - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.g - tgt.b));\n" +
185                    "////use the following line to increase contrast\n" +
186                    "//   vec3 ycc = vec3(v_color.r * dot(sin(tgt.rgb * 1.5707963267948966) * sqrt(tgt.rgb), bright), ((v_color.g - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.r - tgt.b), ((v_color.b - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.g - tgt.b));\n" +
187                    "////use the following line to increase contrast more\n" +
188                    "//   vec3 ycc = vec3(v_color.r * pow(dot(tgt.rgb, bright), 1.25), ((v_color.g - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.r - tgt.b), ((v_color.b - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.g - tgt.b));\n" +
189                    //uses a specific matrix (related to bright, above) multiplied with ycc to get back to rgb.
190                    "   gl_FragColor = vec4( (clamp(mat3(1.0, 1.0, 1.0, 0.625, -0.375, -0.375, -0.5, 0.5, -0.5) * ycc, 0.0, 1.0)), v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
191                    "}";
192    /**
193     * A variant on {@link #fragmentShader} that adjusts luma to make mid-range colors darker, while keeping light
194     * colors light. This is not the same as {@link ColorfulBatch} even when the contrast for ColorfulBatch's tweak is
195     * the same as what this uses (1.375 here, which is roughly 0.875f in a tweak value). ColorfulBatch does some work
196     * in the vertex shader so it may be a little faster than this approach, and it seems to have less severe effects on
197     * the overall brightness of an image that has adjusted contrast.
198     * <br>
199     * You can generate YCwCm colors using any of various methods in the {@code ycwcm} package, such as
200     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}.
201     * <br>
202     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
203     */
204    public static final String fragmentShaderHigherContrast =
205            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
206                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
207                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
208                    "#else\n" +
209                    "#define LOWP \n" +
210                    "#endif\n" +
211                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
212                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
213                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
214                    "const float contrast =    1.375   ; // You can make contrast a uniform if you want.\n" +
215                    "const vec3 bright = vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125) * (4.0 / 3.0);\n" +
216                    "void main()\n" +
217                    "{\n" +
218                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
219                    "   vec3 ycc = vec3(v_color.r - 0.5 + pow(dot(tgt.rgb, bright), contrast) * 0.75, ((v_color.g - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.r - tgt.b), ((v_color.b - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.g - tgt.b));\n" +
220                    "   gl_FragColor = vec4( (clamp(mat3(1.0, 1.0, 1.0, 0.625, -0.375, -0.375, -0.5, 0.5, -0.5) * ycc, 0.0, 1.0)), v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
221                    "}";
222
223    /**
224     * An alternative shader that effectively reduces luma contrast, bringing all but the darkest colors to the
225     * upper-mid luma range. This is not the same as {@link ColorfulBatch} even when the contrast for ColorfulBatch's
226     * tweak is the same as what this uses (0.625 here, which is roughly 0.125f in a tweak value). ColorfulBatch does
227     * some work in the vertex shader so it may be a little faster than this approach, and it seems to have less severe
228     * effects on the overall brightness of an image that has adjusted contrast.
229     * <br>
230     * You can generate YCwCm colors using any of various methods in the {@code ycwcm} package, such as
231     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}.
232     * <br>
233     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
234     */
235    public static final String fragmentShaderLowerContrast = fragmentShaderHigherContrast.replace("   1.375   ", "0.625");
236
237    /**
238     * Prepares and returns a new SpriteBatch that uses the default {@link #vertexShader} and {@link #fragmentShader}
239     * from this class, making it able to render YCwCm colors from the ycwcm package. It won't be a
240     * {@link ColorfulBatch} (those can adjust colors in more ways); you can simply use {@code new ColorfulBatch()} to
241     * make one of those. Note that a SpriteBatch like this produces won't be able to render a {@link ColorfulSprite},
242     * but ColorfulBatch can.
243     * <br>
244     * You can generate YCwCm colors using any of various methods in the {@code ycwcm} package, such as
245     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}.
246     * @return a freshly allocated SpriteBatch that will also have a new ShaderProgram for rendering YCwCm
247     */
248    public static SpriteBatch makeBatch()
249    {
250        ShaderProgram shader = new ShaderProgram(vertexShader, fragmentShader);
251        if(!shader.isCompiled())
252            throw new GdxRuntimeException("Couldn't compile shader: " + shader.getLog());
253        return new SpriteBatch(1000, shader);
254    }
255
256    /**
257     * Prepares and returns a new SpriteBatch that uses the default {@link #vertexShader} and {@link #fragmentShader}
258     * from this class, making it able to render YCwCm colors from the ycwcm package. This also takes a
259     * {@code contrast} parameter; if greater than 1.0 it will make light colors lighter and dark colors darker, while
260     * if it is less than 1.0 it will make all but the darkest colors closer to the upper-middle-range of lightness.
261     * If you want to adjust contrast per-sprite, use a {@link ColorfulBatch} (those can adjust colors in more ways);
262     * you can simply use {@code new ColorfulBatch()} to make one of those. Note that a SpriteBatch like this produces
263     * won't be able to render a {@link ColorfulSprite}, but ColorfulBatch can. ColorfulBatch also will calculate
264     * contrast differently from the shader this uses, including doing some work in the vertex shader (which may be
265     * faster). It also takes a contrast in its tweak value that is limited to a 0.0 to 1.0 range, rather than 0.1 to
266     * 2.0 here (this can technically tolerate 0.01 to 10.0, but those extremes aren't recommended).
267     * <br>
268     * You can generate YCwCm colors using any of various methods in the {@code ycwcm} package, such as
269     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}.
270     * @param contrast how much contrast should be emphasized; higher than 1.0 is more contrasting, and this should usually be between 0.1 and 2.0
271     * @return a freshly allocated SpriteBatch that will also have a new ShaderProgram for rendering YCwCm
272     */
273    public static SpriteBatch makeBatch(final float contrast)
274    {
275        ShaderProgram shader = new ShaderProgram(vertexShader, fragmentShaderHigherContrast.replace("   1.375   ", Float.toString(Math.min(Math.max(contrast, 0.01f), 10f))));
276        if(!shader.isCompiled())
277            throw new GdxRuntimeException("Couldn't compile shader: " + shader.getLog());
278        return new SpriteBatch(1000, shader);
279    }
280
281    /**
282     * Prepares and returns a new SpriteBatch that uses {@link #vertexShaderHSLC} and {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC}
283     * from this class, making it interpret the SpriteBatch's color, as set by 
284     * {@link SpriteBatch#setColor(float, float, float, float)}, to be hue rotation, saturation change, lightness
285     * change, and contrast change. All of these are neutral when their value is 0.5f. Hue rotates clockwise or
286     * counterclockwise when it goes toward 0.0, and the other way when it goes toward 1.0; 0.0 and 1.0 both refer to
287     * the 180 degree rotation, but I don't know which goes which way (it also depends on how you visualize hue).
288     * Saturation becomes more grayscale as it goes towards 0.0, and more vivid as it goes towards 1.0. Lightness gets
289     * darker towards 0.0, lighter towards 1.0 (any lightness above 0.5 will brighten the image, unlike the default
290     * shader and batch color). Contrast affects changes in lightness; low contrast makes all lightness closer to the
291     * mid-range, while high contrast makes even small changes in the mid-range of an image's color have stark lightness
292     * changes in the result. Note, this does not support changing an image's alpha with the batch color.
293     * <br>
294     * You can generate HSLC colors using {@link FloatColors#rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float)}, using the last
295     * parameter to store contrast.
296     * @return a freshly allocated SpriteBatch that will also have a new ShaderProgram for rendering HSLC
297     */
298    public static SpriteBatch makeBatchHSLC()
299    {
300        ShaderProgram shader = new ShaderProgram(vertexShaderHSLC, fragmentShaderHSLC);
301        if(!shader.isCompiled())
302            throw new GdxRuntimeException("Couldn't compile shader: " + shader.getLog());
303        return new SpriteBatch(1000, shader);
304    }
305
306    /**
307     * Similar to {@link #fragmentShader}, but this uses the very perceptually-accurate IPT color space as described by
308     * Ebner and Fairchild, instead of the custom YCwCm color space. IPT doesn't really need that much more computation
309     * to be done by the shader, but tends to make gradual changes in color much smoother. If comparing to YCwCm, then
310     * Y (luma) is like I (intensity) here, so when a Batch color has 0 for I (stored in the r channel), it makes the
311     * image very dark, while if the Batch color has 1 for I, it makes the image very light. Cw and Cm can be graphed
312     * like a color wheel, and in their case, the 4 corners of a square graph are red, yellow, green, and blue. IPT is
313     * less geometrical, and the corners are roughly purple, orange, green, and cyan, while the centers of the edges of
314     * the square are close to red, yellow, green, and blue. <a href="https://i.imgur.com/A3n4qmM.png">See this capture
315     * of the IPT space</a> if you want a better picture. The P (short for protan, a term from ophthalmology) channel
316     * (stored in g) is the left-to-right axis there, with P==0 making colors green or blue (cooler), and P==1 making
317     * colors orange, red, or purple (somewhat warmer). The T (short for tritan, also from ophthalmology) channel
318     * (stored in b) is the down-to-up axis there, with T==0 making colors more blue or purple, and T==1 making colors
319     * more green, yellow, brown, or orange. Where protan can be viewed as going from cool to warm as its value
320     * increases, tritan can be viewed as going from artificial to natural, or perhaps fluid to solid. Alpha is treated
321     * exactly as it is in the standard libGDX fragment shader, with the alpha in the batch color multiplied by the
322     * alpha in the image pixel to get the result alpha.
323     * <br>
324     * You can generate IPT colors using any of various methods in the {@code ipt} package, such as
325     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt.ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}. Note that IPT is
326     * intended to share an API with the {@code ipt_hq} package, but IPT_HQ is usually preferred.
327     * <br>
328     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
329     */
330    public static String fragmentShaderIPT =
331            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
332                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
333                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
334                    "#else\n" +
335                    "#define LOWP \n" +
336                    "#endif\n" +
337                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
338                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
339                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
340                    "void main()\n" +
341                    "{\n" +
342                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
343                    "    vec4 adj = v_color;\n" +
344                    "    adj.yz = adj.yz * 2.0 - 0.5;\n" +
345                    "    vec3 ipt = (mat3(0.189786, 0.669665 , 0.286498, 0.576951, -0.73741 , 0.655205, 0.233221, 0.0681367, -0.941748)\n" +
346                    "         * (tgt.rgb)) + adj.xyz - 0.5;\n" +
347                    "    ipt.x = clamp(ipt.x, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
348                    "    ipt.yz = clamp(ipt.yz, -1.0, 1.0);\n" +
349                    "    vec3 back = mat3(0.999779, 1.00015, 0.999769, 1.07094, -0.377744, 0.0629496, 0.324891, 0.220439, -0.809638) * ipt;\n" +
350                    "    gl_FragColor = vec4(clamp(back, 0.0, 1.0), adj.a * tgt.a);\n" +
351                    "}";
352    /**
353     * Just like {@link #fragmentShaderIPT}, but gamma-corrects the input and output RGB values (which improves
354     * lightness uniformity) and uses an exponential step internally to change how colors are distributed within the
355     * gamut. These steps are more computationally expensive than the bare-bones ones in {@link #fragmentShaderIPT}, but
356     * they seem to improve some aspects of color transitions quite a bit.
357     * <br>
358     * You can generate IPT_HQ colors using any of various methods in the {@code ipt_hq} package, such as
359     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt_hq.ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}. Note that IPT_HQ is
360     * intended to share an API with the {@code ipt} package, but IPT_HQ is usually preferred.
361     * <br>
362     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
363     */
364    public static String fragmentShaderIPT_HQ =
365            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
366                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
367                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
368                    "#else\n" +
369                    "#define LOWP \n" +
370                    "#endif\n" +
371                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
372                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
373                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
374                    "const vec3 forward = vec3(0.43);\n" +
375                    "const vec3 reverse = vec3(1.0 / 0.43);\n" +
376                    "void main()\n" +
377                    "{\n" +
378                    "  vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
379                    "  vec3 ipt = mat3(0.40000, 4.45500, 0.80560, 0.40000, -4.8510, 0.35720, 0.20000, 0.39600, -1.1628) *" +
380                    "             pow(mat3(0.313921, 0.151693, 0.017753, 0.639468, 0.748209, 0.109468, 0.0465970, 0.1000044, 0.8729690) \n" +
381                    "             * (tgt.rgb * tgt.rgb), forward);\n" +
382                    "  ipt.x = clamp(ipt.x + v_color.x - 0.55, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
383                    "  ipt.yz = clamp(ipt.yz + v_color.yz * 2.0 - 1.0, -1.0, 1.0);\n" +
384                    "  ipt = mat3(1.0, 1.0, 1.0, 0.097569, -0.11388, 0.032615, 0.205226, 0.133217, -0.67689) * ipt;\n" +
385                    "  gl_FragColor = vec4(sqrt(clamp(" +
386                    "                 mat3(5.432622, -1.10517, 0.028104, -4.67910, 2.311198, -0.19466, 0.246257, -0.20588, 1.166325) *\n" +
387                    "                 (sign(ipt) * pow(abs(ipt), reverse))," +
388                    "                 0.0, 1.0)), v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
389                    "}";
390
391    /**
392     * Just like {@link #fragmentShaderIPT_HQ}, but uses the Oklab color space instead of the very similar IPT_HQ one.
393     * This also gamma-corrects the inputs and outputs, though it uses subtly different math internally. Oklab colors
394     * tend to have more variation on their L channel, which represents lightness, than their A or B channels, which
395     * represent green-to-red and blue-to-yellow chromatic axes; indeed, A and B tend to be no more than about 1/6 away
396     * from their middle point at 1/2, which is used for grayscale. This is normal for Oklab, and allows colors to be
397     * compared for approximate difference using Euclidean distance. Importantly, Oklab preserves the meaning of its L
398     * channel (lightness) very well when comparing two arbitrary colors, while also doing well when comparing chroma
399     * (see {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab.ColorTools#chroma(float)}.
400     * <br>
401     * You can generate Oklab colors using any of various methods in the {@code oklab} package, such as
402     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab.ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}.
403     * <br>
404     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
405     */
406    public static String fragmentShaderOklab =
407            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
408                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
409                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
410                    "#else\n" +
411                    "#define LOWP \n" +
412                    "#endif\n" +
413                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
414                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
415                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
416                    "const vec3 forward = vec3(1.0 / 3.0);\n" +
417                    "void main()\n" +
418                    "{\n" +
419                    "  vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
420                    "  vec3 lab = mat3(+0.2104542553, +1.9779984951, +0.0259040371, +0.7936177850, -2.4285922050, +0.7827717662, -0.0040720468, +0.4505937099, -0.8086757660) *" +
421                    "             pow(mat3(0.4121656120, 0.2118591070, 0.0883097947, 0.5362752080, 0.6807189584, 0.2818474174, 0.0514575653, 0.1074065790, 0.6302613616) \n" +
422                    "             * (tgt.rgb * tgt.rgb), forward);\n" +
423                    "  lab.x = clamp(lab.x + v_color.r - 0.63, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
424                    "  lab.yz = clamp(lab.yz + v_color.gb * 2.0 - 1.0, -1.0, 1.0);\n" +
425                    "  lab = mat3(1.0, 1.0, 1.0, +0.3963377774, -0.1055613458, -0.0894841775, +0.2158037573, -0.0638541728, -1.2914855480) * lab;\n" +
426                    "  gl_FragColor = vec4(sqrt(clamp(" +
427                    "                 mat3(+4.0767245293, -1.2681437731, -0.0041119885, -3.3072168827, +2.6093323231, -0.7034763098, +0.2307590544, -0.3411344290, +1.7068625689) *\n" +
428                    "                 (lab * lab * lab)," +
429                    "                 0.0, 1.0)), v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
430                    "}";
431
432    /**
433     * A vertex shader that does the bulk of processing HSI-format batch colors and converting them to a format
434     * {@link #fragmentShaderHSI} can use. Since HSI is only a cylindrical/spherical adaptation of IPT, with identical
435     * I components and the combination of H and S in polar coordinates mapping to P and T in Cartesian coordinates,
436     * the fragment shader this is used with can be any that expects an IPT color (currently only
437     * {@link #fragmentShaderIPT} does this, and it's the same as {@link #fragmentShaderHSI}). This vertex shader does
438     * a lot more than most vertex shaders here, but since it is executed relatively rarely (unless you're drawing many
439     * 1-pixel textures), there shouldn't be a heavy performance penalty.
440     * <br>
441     * There is no special code to generate HSI colors; you can use
442     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt.ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}, or any ColorTools
443     * method that generates a packed float color directly from the channel values, to specify hue, saturation,
444     * intensity, and alpha in that order. You can also just specify the batch color directly with
445     * {@link SpriteBatch#setColor(float, float, float, float)}, taking the channels in the same order as above.
446     * <br>
447     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
448     */
449    public static final String vertexShaderHSI = "attribute vec4 " + ShaderProgram.POSITION_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
450        + "attribute vec4 " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
451        + "attribute vec2 " + ShaderProgram.TEXCOORD_ATTRIBUTE + "0;\n"
452        + "uniform mat4 u_projTrans;\n"
453        + "varying vec4 v_color;\n"
454        + "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n"
455        + "const vec3 yellow  = vec3( 0.16155326,0.020876605,-0.26078433 );\n"
456        + "const vec3 magenta = vec3(-0.16136102,0.122068435,-0.070396   );\n"
457        + "const vec3 cyan    = vec3( 0.16420607,0.3481738,   0.104959644);\n"
458        + "void main()\n"
459        + "{\n"
460        + "    v_color = " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
461        + "    v_color.a = " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ".a * (255.0/254.0);\n"
462        + "    vec3 hsi = v_color.rgb;\n"
463        + "    v_color.x = (hsi.z - 0.5) * 0.9999;\n"
464        + "    hsi.x *= 6.28318;\n"
465        + "    hsi.y *= 0.5;\n"
466        + "    v_color.y = cos(hsi.x) * hsi.y;\n"
467        + "    v_color.z = sin(hsi.x) * hsi.y;\n"
468        + "    float crMid = dot(cyan.yz, v_color.yz);\n"
469        + "    float mgMid = dot(magenta.yz, v_color.yz);\n"
470        + "    float ybMid = dot(yellow.yz, v_color.yz);\n"
471        + "    float crScale = (v_color.x - 0.5 + step(crMid, 0.0)) * cyan.x / (0.00001 - crMid);\n"
472        + "    float mgScale = (v_color.x + 0.5 - step(mgMid, 0.0)) * magenta.x / (0.00001 - mgMid);\n"
473        + "    float ybScale = (v_color.x - 0.5 + step(ybMid, 0.0)) * yellow.x / (0.00001 - ybMid);\n"
474        + "    float scale = 4.0 * min(crScale, min(mgScale, ybScale));\n"
475        + "    v_color.yz *= scale * length(v_color.yz) / cos(3.14159 * v_color.x);\n"
476        + "    v_color.xyz += 0.5;\n"
477        + "    v_texCoords = " + ShaderProgram.TEXCOORD_ATTRIBUTE + "0;\n"
478        + "    gl_Position =  u_projTrans * " + ShaderProgram.POSITION_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
479        + "}\n";
480    /**
481     * This is an alias for {@link #fragmentShaderIPT}. If used with {@link #vertexShaderHSI}, you can specify a batch
482     * color using an HSL-like system.
483     * <br>
484     * There is no special code to generate HSI colors; you can use
485     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt.ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}, or any ColorTools
486     * method that generates a packed float color directly from the channel values, to specify hue, saturation,
487     * intensity, and alpha in that order. You can also just specify the batch color directly with
488     * {@link SpriteBatch#setColor(float, float, float, float)}, taking the channels in the same order as above.
489     * <br>
490     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShaderHSI}.
491     */
492    public static String fragmentShaderHSI = fragmentShaderIPT;
493
494    /**
495     * Not a full shader, this is a snippet used by most of the other HSL-based shaders to implement the complex
496     * rgb2hsl() and hsl2rgb() methods. There are also comments in the code snippet that you can use if you want to
497     * change the distribution of colors across the color wheel.
498     * <br>
499     * Credit to Sam Hocevar, https://gamedev.stackexchange.com/a/59808 .
500     * <br>
501     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
502     */
503    public static final String partialCodeHSL =
504                    "const float eps = 1.0e-10;\n" +
505                    "////Call this to go from the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) to a\n" +
506                    "////different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).\n" +
507                    "//float official2primaries(float hue) {\n" +
508                    "//    return  hue * (  2.137\n" +
509                    "//          + hue * (  0.542\n" +
510                    "//          + hue * (-15.141\n" +
511                    "//          + hue * ( 30.120\n" +
512                    "//          + hue * (-22.541\n" +
513                    "//          + hue *   5.883)))));\n" +
514                    "//}\n" +
515                    "////Call this to go to the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) from a\n" +
516                    "////different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).\n" +
517                    "//float primaries2official(float hue) {\n" +
518                    "//    return  hue * (  0.677\n" +
519                    "//          + hue * ( -0.123\n" +
520                    "//          + hue * (-11.302\n" +
521                    "//          + hue * ( 46.767\n" +
522                    "//          + hue * (-58.493\n" +
523                    "//          + hue *   23.474)))));\n" +
524                    "//}\n" +
525                    "vec4 rgb2hsl(vec4 c)\n" +
526                    "{\n" +
527                    "    const vec4 J = vec4(0.0, -1.0 / 3.0, 2.0 / 3.0, -1.0);\n" +
528                    "    vec4 p = mix(vec4(c.bg, J.wz), vec4(c.gb, J.xy), step(c.b, c.g));\n" +
529                    "    vec4 q = mix(vec4(p.xyw, c.r), vec4(c.r, p.yzx), step(p.x, c.r));\n" +
530                    "    float d = q.x - min(q.w, q.y);\n" +
531                    "    float l = q.x * (1.0 - 0.5 * d / (q.x + eps));\n" +
532                    "    return vec4(abs(q.z + (q.w - q.y) / (6.0 * d + eps)), (q.x - l) / (min(l, 1.0 - l) + eps), l, c.a);\n" +
533                    "}\n" +
534                    "\n" +
535                    "vec4 hsl2rgb(vec4 c)\n" +
536                    "{\n" +
537                    "    const vec4 K = vec4(1.0, 2.0 / 3.0, 1.0 / 3.0, 3.0);\n" +
538                    "    vec3 p = abs(fract(c.x + K.xyz) * 6.0 - K.www);\n" +
539                    "    float v = (c.z + c.y * min(c.z, 1.0 - c.z));\n" +
540                    "    return vec4(v * mix(K.xxx, clamp(p - K.xxx, 0.0, 1.0), 2.0 * (1.0 - c.z / (v + eps))), c.w);\n" +
541                    "}";
542
543    /**
544     * Adjusted-hue version of {@link #partialCodeHSL}, supplying HSL to-and-from RGB conversions with a smaller range
545     * of hue used for cyan and a larger range for orange. Not currently used. This is pretty much only meant so people
546     * reading the source code and trying different variations on HSL can see some of the attempts I made.
547     * <br>
548     * Credit to Sam Hocevar, https://gamedev.stackexchange.com/a/59808 .
549     * <br>
550     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
551     */
552    public static final String partialCodeHSLStretched =
553            "const float eps = 1.0e-10;\n" +
554                    //// maybe not blue enough?
555//                    //Call this to go from the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) to a
556//                    //different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).
557//                    "float official2primaries(float hue) {\n" +
558//                    "    return  hue * (  1.630\n" +
559//                    "          + hue * (  5.937\n" +
560//                    "          + hue * (-38.485\n" +
561//                    "          + hue * ( 76.101\n" +
562//                    "          + hue * (-63.977\n" +
563//                    "          + hue *   19.794)))));\n" +
564//                    "}\n" +
565//                    //Call this to go to the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) from a
566//                    //different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).
567//                    "float primaries2official(float hue) {\n" +
568//                    "    return  hue * (  1.463\n" +
569//                    "          + hue * ( -9.834\n" +
570//                    "          + hue * ( 31.153\n" +
571//                    "          + hue * (-35.066\n" +
572//                    "          + hue *   13.284))));\n" +
573//                    "}\n" +
574                    //// still weirdly high orange
575//                    "float official2primaries(float hue) {\n" +
576//                    "    return  hue * (  2.634\n" +
577//                    "          + hue * ( -4.703\n" +
578//                    "          + hue * (  3.659\n" +
579//                    "          + hue * (  0.829\n" +
580//                    "          + hue *   -1.419))));\n" +
581//                    "}\n" +
582//                    "float primaries2official(float hue) {\n" +
583//                    "    return  hue * (  1.163\n" +
584//                    "          + hue * ( -7.102\n" +
585//                    "          + hue * ( 22.709\n" +
586//                    "          + hue * (-25.502\n" +
587//                    "          + hue *    9.732))));\n" +
588//                    "}\n" +
589//                    "const float ROOT   = 16.0;\n" +
590//                    "const float SQUARE = ROOT * ROOT;\n" +
591                    "float official2primaries(float hue) {\n" +
592//                    "    return (sqrt(hue * 0.9375 + 0.0625) - 0.25) * 1.333;\n" +
593//                    "    return asin(sqrt(hue * SQUARE) * (1.0 / ROOT)) * (2.0 * 3.14159274);\n" +
594
595//                    "    return asin((sqrt(hue * 0.9375 + 0.0625) - 0.25) * 2.666 - 1.0) * 0.318309886 + 0.5;\n" +
596
597//                    "    return sqrt(sin((hue - 0.5) * 3.14159274) * 0.5 + 0.5);\n" +
598//                    "    return pow(hue, 0.5625);\n" +
599//                    "    return sqrt(hue);\n" +
600                    "    return (sqrt(hue + 0.050625) - 0.225) * 1.25;\n" +
601                    "}\n" +
602                    "float primaries2official(float hue) {\n" +
603//                    "    hue = sin((hue) * (0.5 * 3.14159274));\n" +
604//                    "    hue = (hue) * 0.75 + 0.25;\n" +
605                    
606//                    "    hue = sin((hue - 0.5) * 3.14159274);\n" +
607//                    "    hue = (hue + 1.0) * 0.375 + 0.25;\n" +
608//                    "    return (hue * hue - 0.0625) * (1.0 / 0.9375);\n" +
609                    
610//                    "    return asin(hue * hue * 2.0 - 1.0) * 0.318309886 + 0.5;\n" +
611//                    "    return pow(hue, 1.77777);\n" +
612                    "    return pow(hue * 0.8 + 0.225, 2.0) - 0.050625;\n" +
613//                    "    return hue * hue;\n" +
614
615//                    "    hue = sin((hue) * (0.5 * 3.14159274));\n" +
616//                    "    hue = hue * ROOT;\n" +
617//                    "    return (hue * hue) * (1.0 / SQUARE);\n" +
618
619                    "}\n" +
620                    //// way too much orange?
621//                    //Call this to go from the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) to a
622//                    //different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).
623//                    "float official2primaries(float hue) {\n" +
624//                    "    return  hue * (  2.137\n" +
625//                    "          + hue * (  0.542\n" +
626//                    "          + hue * (-15.141\n" +
627//                    "          + hue * ( 30.120\n" +
628//                    "          + hue * (-22.541\n" +
629//                    "          + hue *    5.883)))));\n" +
630//                    "}\n" +
631//                    //Call this to go to the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) from a
632//                    //different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).
633//                    "float primaries2official(float hue) {\n" +
634//                    "    return  hue * (  0.677\n" +
635//                    "          + hue * ( -0.123\n" +
636//                    "          + hue * (-11.302\n" +
637//                    "          + hue * ( 46.767\n" +
638//                    "          + hue * (-58.493\n" +
639//                    "          + hue *   23.474)))));\n" +
640//                    "}\n" +
641                    "vec4 rgb2hsl(vec4 c)\n" +
642                    "{\n" +
643                    "    const vec4 J = vec4(0.0, -1.0 / 3.0, 2.0 / 3.0, -1.0);\n" +
644                    "    vec4 p = mix(vec4(c.bg, J.wz), vec4(c.gb, J.xy), step(c.b, c.g));\n" +
645                    "    vec4 q = mix(vec4(p.xyw, c.r), vec4(c.r, p.yzx), step(p.x, c.r));\n" +
646                    "\n" +
647                    "    float d = q.x - min(q.w, q.y);\n" +
648                    "    float l = q.x * (1.0 - 0.5 * d / (q.x + eps));\n" +
649                    "    return vec4(official2primaries(abs(q.z + (q.w - q.y) / (6.0 * d + eps))), (q.x - l) / (min(l, 1.0 - l) + eps), l, c.a);\n" +
650                    "}\n" +
651                    "\n" +
652                    "vec4 hsl2rgb(vec4 c)\n" +
653                    "{\n" +
654                    "    const vec4 K = vec4(1.0, 2.0 / 3.0, 1.0 / 3.0, 3.0);\n" +
655                    "    vec3 p = abs(fract(primaries2official(c.x) + K.xyz) * 6.0 - K.www);\n" +
656                    "    float v = (c.z + c.y * min(c.z, 1.0 - c.z));\n" +
657                    "    return vec4(v * mix(K.xxx, clamp(p - K.xxx, 0.0, 1.0), 2.0 * (1.0 - c.z / (v + eps))), c.w);\n" +
658                    "}";
659    /**
660     * This GLSL snippet takes an RGB vec3 and a float that represents a hue rotation in radians, and returns the
661     * rotated RGB vec3. It is not a full shader, and is used by inserting it into shader code to provide the applyHue()
662     * method to that code.
663     * <br>
664     * Credit for this challenging method goes to Andrey-Postelzhuk,
665     * <a href="https://forum.unity.com/threads/hue-saturation-brightness-contrast-shader.260649/">Unity Forums</a>.
666     */
667    public static final String partialHueRodrigues =
668            "vec3 applyHue(vec3 rgb, float hue)\n" +
669                    "{\n" +
670                    "    vec3 k = vec3(0.57735);\n" +
671                    "    float c = cos(hue);\n" +
672                    "    //Rodrigues' rotation formula\n" +
673                    "    return rgb * c + cross(k, rgb) * sin(hue) + k * dot(k, rgb) * (1.0 - c);\n" +
674                    "}\n";
675
676
677    /**
678     * Treats the color as hue, saturation, lightness, and... uh... well, this is pretty much only useful when the batch
679     * color's {@code a} is 1 . You probably want {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC} or {@link #fragmentShaderHSLA}.
680     * <br>
681     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
682     */
683    public static final String fragmentShaderHSL =
684            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
685                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
686                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
687                    "#else\n" +
688                    "#define LOWP \n" +
689                    "#endif\n" +
690                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
691                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
692                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
693                    partialCodeHSL +
694                    "void main()\n" +
695                    "{\n" +
696                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
697                    "   vec4 hsl = rgb2hsl(tgt);\n" +
698                    "   hsl.x = fract((fract(v_color.x + 0.5 - hsl.x) - 0.5) * v_color.w + hsl.x);\n" +
699                    "   hsl.yz = mix(hsl.yz, v_color.yz, v_color.w);\n" +
700                    "   gl_FragColor = hsl2rgb(hsl);\n" +
701                    "}";
702
703    /**
704     * I can't even remember what this does, to be honest. It's probably not what you want. Instead, you probably want
705     * {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC} or {@link #fragmentShaderHSLA}.
706     * <br>
707     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
708     */
709    public static final String fragmentShaderRotateHSL =
710            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
711                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
712                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
713                    "#else\n" +
714                    "#define LOWP \n" +
715                    "#endif\n" +
716                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
717                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
718                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
719                    partialCodeHSL +
720                    "void main()\n" +
721                    "{\n" +
722                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
723                    "   vec4 hsl = rgb2hsl(tgt);\n" +
724                    "   hsl.x = fract(v_color.x + hsl.x + 0.5);\n" +
725                    "   hsl.yz = clamp(hsl.yz * v_color.yz * 2.0, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
726                    "   gl_FragColor = hsl2rgb(hsl);\n" +
727                    "}";
728
729    /**
730     * This is similar to the default vertex shader from libGDX, but also sets a varying value for contrast. It is
731     * needed if you use {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC}.
732     */
733    public static final String vertexShaderHSLC = "attribute vec4 a_position;\n"
734            + "attribute vec4 a_color;\n"
735            + "attribute vec2 a_texCoord0;\n"
736            + "uniform mat4 u_projTrans;\n"
737            + "varying vec4 v_color;\n"
738            + "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" 
739            + "varying float v_lightFix;\n"
740            + "\n"
741            + "void main()\n"
742            + "{\n"
743            + "   v_color = a_color;\n"
744            + "   v_texCoords = a_texCoord0;\n"
745            + "   v_color.a = pow(v_color.a * (255.0/254.0) + 0.5, 1.709);\n"    
746            + "   v_lightFix = 1.0 + pow(v_color.a, 1.41421356);\n"
747            + "   gl_Position =  u_projTrans * a_position;\n"
748            + "}\n";
749
750    /**
751     * Allows changing Hue/Saturation/Lightness/Contrast, with hue as a rotation. If hue continuously goes from 0 to 1,
752     * then 0 to 1, 0 to 1, and so on, then this will smoothly rotate the hue of the image.
753     * <br>
754     * You can generate HSLC colors using methods like {@link FloatColors#rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float)}.
755     * <br>
756     * Credit for HLSL version goes to Andrey-Postelzhuk,
757     * <a href="https://forum.unity.com/threads/hue-saturation-brightness-contrast-shader.260649/">Unity Forums</a>.
758     * The YCC adaptation, and different approach to contrast (this has close to neutral contrast when a is 0.5,
759     * while the original had a fair bit higher contrast than expected), is from this codebase.
760     * <br>
761     * Meant only for use with {@link #vertexShaderHSLC}, which sets {@code varying float v_lightFix} so contrast can
762     * use it.
763     */
764    public static final String fragmentShaderHSLC = 
765                    "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
766                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
767                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
768                    "#else\n" +
769                    "#define LOWP \n" +
770                    "#endif\n" +
771                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
772                    "varying float v_lightFix;\n" +
773                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
774                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
775                            partialHueRodrigues +
776                    "void main()\n" +
777                    "{\n" +
778                    "    float hue = 6.2831853 * (v_color.x - 0.5);\n" +
779                    "    float saturation = v_color.y * 2.0;\n" +
780                    "    float brightness = v_color.z - 0.5;\n" +
781                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
782                    "    tgt.rgb = applyHue(tgt.rgb, hue);\n" +
783                    "    tgt.rgb = vec3(\n" +
784                    "     (0.5 * pow(dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125)), v_color.w) * v_lightFix + brightness),\n" + // lightness
785                    "     ((tgt.r - tgt.b) * saturation),\n" + // warmth
786                    "     ((tgt.g - tgt.b) * saturation));\n" + // mildness
787                    "    gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(\n" +
788                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, 0.625, -0.5)),\n" + // back to red
789                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, 0.5)),\n" + // back to green
790                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, -0.5)),\n" + // back to blue
791                    "     tgt.a), 0.0, 1.0);\n" + // keep alpha, then clamp
792                    "}";
793    /**
794     * Allows changing Hue/Saturation/Lightness/Alpha, with hue as a rotation.
795     * <br>
796     * You can generate HSLA colors using methods like {@link FloatColors#rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float)}.
797     * <br>
798     * Credit for HLSL version goes to Andrey-Postelzhuk,
799     * <a href="https://forum.unity.com/threads/hue-saturation-brightness-contrast-shader.260649/">Unity Forums</a>.
800     * The YCC adaptation, and change to use alpha, is from this codebase.
801     * <br>
802     * Meant to be used with {@link #vertexShader}, unlike what {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC} expects.
803     */
804    public static final String fragmentShaderHSLA = 
805                    "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
806                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
807                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
808                    "#else\n" +
809                    "#define LOWP \n" +
810                    "#endif\n" +
811                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
812                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
813                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
814                            partialHueRodrigues +
815                    "void main()\n" +
816                    "{\n" +
817                    "    float hue = 6.2831853 * (v_color.x - 0.5);\n" +
818                    "    float saturation = v_color.y * 2.0;\n" +
819                    "    float brightness = v_color.z - 0.5;\n" +
820                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
821                    "    tgt.rgb = applyHue(tgt.rgb, hue);\n" +
822                    "    tgt.rgb = vec3(\n" +
823                    "     (dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125)) + brightness),\n" + // lightness
824                    "     ((tgt.r - tgt.b) * saturation),\n" + // warmth
825                    "     ((tgt.g - tgt.b) * saturation));\n" + // mildness
826                    "    gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(\n" +
827                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, 0.625, -0.5)),\n" + // back to red
828                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, 0.5)),\n" + // back to green
829                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, -0.5)),\n" + // back to blue
830                    "     tgt.a * v_color.w), 0.0, 1.0);\n" + // keep alpha, then clamp
831                    "}";
832    /**
833     * Generally a lower-quality hue rotation than {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC}; this is here as a work in progress.
834     * <br>
835     * You can generate HSLC colors using methods like {@link FloatColors#rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float)}.
836     * <br>
837     * Meant to be used with {@link #vertexShaderHSLC}, which sets {@code varying float v_lightFix} so
838     * contrast can use it.
839     * <br>
840     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
841     */
842    public static final String fragmentShaderHSLC2 = 
843                    "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
844                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
845                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
846                    "#else\n" +
847                    "#define LOWP \n" +
848                    "#endif\n" +
849                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
850                    "varying float v_lightFix;\n" +
851                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
852                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
853                            partialCodeHSL +
854                    "void main()\n" +
855                    "{\n" +
856                    "    float hue = (v_color.x - 0.5);\n" +
857                    "    float saturation = v_color.y * 2.0;\n" +
858                    "    float brightness = v_color.z - 0.5;\n" +
859                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
860                    "    tgt = rgb2hsl(tgt);\n" +
861                    "    tgt.r = fract(tgt.r + hue);\n" +
862                    "    tgt = hsl2rgb(tgt);\n" +
863                    "    tgt.rgb = vec3(\n" +
864                    "     (0.5 * pow(dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125)), v_color.w) * v_lightFix + brightness),\n" + // lightness
865                    "     ((tgt.r - tgt.b) * saturation),\n" + // warmth
866                    "     ((tgt.g - tgt.b) * saturation));\n" + // mildness
867                    "    gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(\n" +
868                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, 0.625, -0.5)),\n" + // back to red
869                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, 0.5)),\n" + // back to green
870                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, -0.5)),\n" + // back to blue
871                    "     tgt.a), 0.0, 1.0);\n" + // keep alpha, then clamp
872                    "}";
873    /**
874     * Cycles lightness in a psychedelic way as hue and lightness change; not a general-purpose usage.
875     * <br>
876     * You can generate HSLC colors using methods like {@link FloatColors#rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float)}.
877     * <br>
878     * Meant to be used with {@link #vertexShaderHSLC}, which sets {@code varying float v_lightFix} so
879     * contrast can use it.
880     * <br>
881     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
882     */
883    public static final String fragmentShaderHSLC3 =
884            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
885                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
886                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
887                    "#else\n" +
888                    "#define LOWP \n" +
889                    "#endif\n" +
890                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
891                    "varying float v_lightFix;\n" +
892                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
893                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
894                    "vec3 applyHue(vec3 rgb, float hue)\n" +
895                    partialHueRodrigues +
896                    "void main()\n" +
897                    "{\n" +
898                    "    float hue = 6.2831853 * (v_color.x - 0.5);\n" +
899                    "    float saturation = v_color.y * 2.0;\n" +
900                    "    float brightness = v_color.z - 0.5;\n" +
901                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
902                    "    tgt.rgb = applyHue(tgt.rgb, hue);\n" +
903                    "    tgt.rgb = vec3(\n" +
904                    "     (0.5 * pow(dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125)), v_color.w) * v_lightFix),\n" + // lightness
905                    "     ((tgt.r - tgt.b) * saturation),\n" + // warmth
906                    "     ((tgt.g - tgt.b) * saturation));\n" + // mildness
907                    "    tgt.r = sin((tgt.r + brightness) * 6.2831853) * 0.5 + 0.5;\n" +
908                    "    gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(\n" +
909                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, 0.625, -0.5)),\n" + // back to red
910                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, 0.5)),\n" + // back to green
911                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, -0.5)),\n" + // back to blue
912                    "     tgt.a), 0.0, 1.0);\n" + // keep alpha, then clamp
913                    "}";
914    /**
915     * Cycles hue, but not lightness; otherwise this is like {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC3} without contrast, and keeping
916     * alpha intact. Internally, this uses Sam Hocevar's RGB/HSL conversion instead of Andrey-Postelzhuk's HSLC code.
917     * <br>
918     * You can generate HSLA colors using methods like {@link FloatColors#rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float)}.
919     * <br>
920     * Expects the vertex shader to be {@link #vertexShader}, not the HSLC variant.
921     * <br>
922     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
923     */
924    public static final String fragmentShaderHSLPsychedelic =
925            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
926                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
927                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
928                    "#else\n" +
929                    "#define LOWP \n" +
930                    "#endif\n" +
931                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
932                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
933                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
934                    partialCodeHSL +
935                    "void main()\n" +
936                    "{\n" +
937                    "    float hue = v_color.x - 0.5;\n" +
938                    "    float saturation = v_color.y * 2.0;\n" +
939                    "    float brightness = v_color.z - 0.5;\n" +
940                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
941                    "    tgt = rgb2hsl(tgt);\n" +
942                    "    tgt.x = fract(tgt.x + hue);\n" +
943                    "    tgt.y = clamp(tgt.y * saturation, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
944                    "    tgt.z = clamp(brightness + tgt.z, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
945                    "    gl_FragColor = hsl2rgb(tgt);\n" +
946                    "}";
947
948    /**
949     * One of the more useful HSL shaders here, this takes a batch color as hue, saturation, lightness, and power,
950     * with hue as a target hue and power used to determine how much of the target color should be used. There is no
951     * neutral value for hue, saturation, or lightness, but if power is 0, then the source color will be used
952     * exactly. On the other hand, if power is 1.0, then all pixels will be the target color. Hue is specified from
953     * 0.0 to 1.0, with 0.0 as red, about 0.3 as green, about 0.6 as blue, etc. Saturation is specified from 0.0 to 1.0,
954     * with 0.0 as grayscale and 1.0 as a fully-saturated target color. Lightness is specified from 0.0 to 1.0, with 0.0
955     * as black, the 0.3 to 0.7 range as most colors, and 1.0 white; saturation is clamped to a smaller value as
956     * lightness moves away from 0.5 (toward black or white).
957     * <br>
958     * You can generate HSL(P) colors using methods like {@link FloatColors#rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float)}.
959     */
960    public static final String fragmentShaderHSLP =
961            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
962                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
963                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
964                    "#else\n" +
965                    "#define LOWP \n" +
966                    "#endif\n" +
967                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
968                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
969                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
970                    partialCodeHSL +
971                    "void main()\n" +
972                    "{\n" +
973                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
974                    "   vec4 hsl = rgb2hsl(tgt);\n" +
975                    "   hsl.xy = vec2(cos(hsl.x * 6.2831853), sin(hsl.x * 6.2831853)) * hsl.y;\n" +
976                    "   vec3 tint = vec3(cos(v_color.x * 6.2831853) * v_color.y, sin(v_color.x * 6.2831853) * v_color.y, v_color.z);\n" +
977                    "   hsl.xyz = mix(hsl.xyz, tint, v_color.w);\n" +
978                    "   hsl.xy = vec2(fract(atan(hsl.y, hsl.x) / 6.2831853), length(hsl.xy));\n" +
979                    "   gl_FragColor = hsl2rgb(hsl);\n" +
980                    "}";
981
982    /**
983     * This is supposed to look for RGBA colors that are similar to {@code search}, and if it finds
984     * one, to replace it with {@code replace} (also an RGBA color). It isn't great at the searching part.
985     * <br>
986     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
987     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
988     * <br>
989     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
990     */
991    public static final String fragmentShaderReplacement = 
992                    "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
993                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
994                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
995                    "#else\n" +
996                    "#define LOWP \n" +
997                    "#endif\n" +
998                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
999                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
1000                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
1001                    "uniform vec4 u_search;\n" +
1002                    "uniform vec4 u_replace;\n" +
1003                    "void main()\n" +
1004                    "{\n" +
1005                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D(u_texture, v_texCoords);\n" +
1006                    "   float curve = smoothstep(0.0, 1.0, 1.25 - distance(tgt.rgb, u_search.rgb) * 2.0);\n" +
1007                    "   gl_FragColor = vec4(mix(tgt.rgb, u_replace.rgb, curve), tgt.a) * v_color;\n" +
1008                    "}";
1009    /**
1010     * A drop-in replacement for the default fragment shader that eliminates lightness differences in the output colors.
1011     * Specifically, it does the normal SpriteBatch shader's step with the multiplicative batch color, converts to IPT,
1012     * sets intensity to 0.5, shrinks the P and T components so the color is less saturated, and then converts back to
1013     * an RGBA color. Even though this uses IPT internally, it expects the batch color to be normal RGBA.
1014     * <br>
1015     * Editing this shader is strongly encouraged to fit your needs!
1016     * <br>
1017     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
1018     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
1019     * <br>
1020     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
1021     * @see #fragmentShaderConfigurableContrast a per-sprite-configurable version of this
1022     */
1023    public static String fragmentShaderFlatLightness =
1024  "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
1025  "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
1026  "precision mediump float;\n" +
1027  "#else\n" +
1028  "#define LOWP \n" +
1029  "#endif\n" +
1030  "#define TARGET_LIGHTNESS 0.5 \n" +
1031  "#define SATURATION_CHANGE 1.0 \n" +
1032  "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
1033  "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
1034  "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
1035  "void main()\n" +
1036  "{\n" +
1037  "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
1038  "    vec3 ipt = (mat3(0.189786, 0.669665 , 0.286498, 0.576951, -0.73741 , 0.655205, 0.233221, 0.0681367, -0.941748)\n" +
1039  "         * (tgt.rgb * v_color.rgb));\n" +
1040  "    ipt.x = TARGET_LIGHTNESS;\n" + // change to desired lightness or pass in a lightness as a uniform
1041  "//    ipt.x = (ipt.x - 0.5) * 0.25 + TARGET_LIGHTNESS;\n" + // an alternative way that preserves a tiny bit of original lightness
1042  "    ipt.yz *= SATURATION_CHANGE;\n" + // multiplies saturation by SATURATION_CHANGE, which may be more or less than 1.0
1043  "    vec3 back = clamp(mat3(0.999779, 1.00015, 0.999769, 1.07094, -0.377744, 0.0629496, 0.324891, 0.220439, -0.809638) * ipt, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
1044  "    gl_FragColor = vec4(back, v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
1045  "}";
1046    /**
1047     * A specialized shader that can reduce lightness differences in the output colors, saturate/desaturate them, and
1048     * can be configured to use some of the existing lightness in the image to add to a main flat lightness.
1049     * Specifically, it takes the fragment color (typically a pixel in a texture), converts to IPT, does a calculation
1050     * involving the intensity of the fragment color where the batch color's blue channel affects how much that
1051     * intensity is used, adds the red channel of the batch color, multiplies the P and T components by the green
1052     * channel times 2.0 to saturate or desaturate, and then converts back to an RGBA color. The neutral value for this
1053     * is the RGBA color 0.5, 0.5, 1.0, 1.0 . A typical usage to achieve a fog effect would be to raise lightness (r),
1054     * slightly reduce saturation (g), sharply flatten the original texture's lightness (b), and leave alpha alone (a):
1055     * 0.7, 0.4, 0.2, 1.0 .
1056     * <br>
1057     * This doesn't use a standard type of color; you should use something like
1058     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)} to set the channels in
1059     * the specific way this uses them.
1060     * <br>
1061     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
1062     * @see #fragmentShaderFlatLightness if you only need one contrast setting and still want to set color tints
1063     */
1064    public static String fragmentShaderConfigurableContrast =
1065            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
1066                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
1067                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
1068                    "#else\n" +
1069                    "#define LOWP \n" +
1070                    "#endif\n" +
1071                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
1072                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
1073                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
1074                    "void main()\n" +
1075                    "{\n" +
1076                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
1077                    "    vec3 ipt = (mat3(0.189786, 0.669665 , 0.286498, 0.576951, -0.73741 , 0.655205, 0.233221, 0.0681367, -0.941748)\n" +
1078                    "         * tgt.rgb);\n" +
1079                    "    ipt.x = (ipt.x - 0.5) * v_color.b + v_color.r;\n" + // preserves some lightness based on b, sets main lightness with r
1080                    "    ipt.yz *= v_color.g * 2.0;\n" + // the green channel affects saturation; if it's 0.5 it won't change saturation.
1081                    "    vec3 back = clamp(mat3(0.999779, 1.00015, 0.999769, 1.07094, -0.377744, 0.0629496, 0.324891, 0.220439, -0.809638) * ipt, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
1082                    "    gl_FragColor = vec4(back, v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
1083                    "}";
1084
1085    /**
1086     * A day/night cycle shader that can be used without any other parts of this library. This only needs setting the
1087     * uniform {@code u_timeOfDay} to any float; the rate at which you change this float affects how fast the day/night
1088     * cycle occurs. This is meant to be used with {@link #fragmentShaderDayNight}. Together, they make the color
1089     * adjustment go from bluish and dark at night, to purplish at dawn, to orange/yellow and bright at mid-day, toward
1090     * red at dusk, and then back to bluish at night. This uses an RGBA batch color.
1091     * <br>
1092     * Editing this shader is strongly encouraged to fit your needs! The time-based variables st, ct, and dd can all be
1093     * adjusted to increase or decrease the strength of the effect, and their effects can also be adjusted upon v_color
1094     * and v_tweak.
1095     * <br>
1096     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
1097     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
1098     */
1099    public static String vertexShaderDayNight = "attribute vec4 " + ShaderProgram.POSITION_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
1100            + "attribute vec4 " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
1101            + "attribute vec2 " + ShaderProgram.TEXCOORD_ATTRIBUTE + "0;\n"
1102            + "uniform mat4 u_projTrans;\n"
1103            + "uniform float u_timeOfDay;\n"
1104            + "varying vec4 v_color;\n"
1105            + "varying vec4 v_tweak;\n"
1106            + "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n"
1107            + "varying float v_lightFix;\n"
1108            + "const vec3 forward = vec3(1.0 / 3.0);\n"
1109            + "\n"
1110            + "void main()\n"
1111            + "{\n"
1112            + "   float st = sin(1.5707963 * sin(0.2617994 * u_timeOfDay)); // Whenever st is very high or low... \n"
1113            + "   float ct = sin(1.5707963 * cos(0.2617994 * u_timeOfDay)); // ...ct is close to 0, and vice versa. \n"
1114            + "   float dd = ct * ct; // Positive, small; used for dawn and dusk. \n"
1115            + "   v_color = " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
1116            + "   v_color.w = v_color.w * (255.0/254.0);\n"
1117            + "   vec3 oklab = mat3(+0.2104542553, +1.9779984951, +0.0259040371, +0.7936177850, -2.4285922050, +0.7827717662, -0.0040720468, +0.4505937099, -0.8086757660) *"
1118            + "     pow(mat3(0.4121656120, 0.2118591070, 0.0883097947, 0.5362752080, 0.6807189584, 0.2818474174, 0.0514575653, 0.1074065790, 0.6302613616) \n"
1119            + "     * (v_color.rgb * v_color.rgb), forward);\n"
1120            + "   // The next four lines make use of the time-based variables st, ct, and dd. Edit to fit. \n"
1121            + "   v_color.x = clamp(oklab.x + (0.0625 * st), 0.0, 1.0);\n"
1122            + "   v_color.yz = clamp(oklab.yz + vec2(0.0625 * dd + 0.03125 * st, 0.1 * st), -1.0, 1.0) * ((dd + 0.25) * 0.5);\n"
1123            + "   v_tweak = vec4(0.2 * st + 0.5);\n"
1124            + "   v_tweak.w = pow((1.0 - 0.125 * st), 1.709);\n"
1125            + "   v_lightFix = 1.0 + pow(v_tweak.w, 1.41421356);\n"
1126            + "   v_texCoords = " + ShaderProgram.TEXCOORD_ATTRIBUTE + "0;\n"
1127            + "   gl_Position =  u_projTrans * " + ShaderProgram.POSITION_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
1128            + "}\n";
1129    /**
1130     * The fragment shader counterpart to {@link #vertexShaderDayNight}; must be used with that vertex shader. See its
1131     * docs for more info, particularly about the one uniform this needs set. This uses an RGBA batch color.
1132     * <br>
1133     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
1134     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
1135     * <br>
1136     * Meant only for use with {@link #vertexShaderDayNight}.
1137     */
1138    public static String fragmentShaderDayNight =
1139            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
1140                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
1141                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
1142                    "#else\n" +
1143                    "#define LOWP \n" +
1144                    "#endif\n" +
1145                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
1146                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
1147                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_tweak;\n" +
1148                    "varying float v_lightFix;\n" +
1149                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
1150                    "const vec3 forward = vec3(1.0 / 3.0);\n" +
1151                    "void main()\n" +
1152                    "{\n" +
1153                    "  vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
1154                    "  vec3 lab = mat3(+0.2104542553, +1.9779984951, +0.0259040371, +0.7936177850, -2.4285922050, +0.7827717662, -0.0040720468, +0.4505937099, -0.8086757660) *" +
1155                    "             pow(mat3(0.4121656120, 0.2118591070, 0.0883097947, 0.5362752080, 0.6807189584, 0.2818474174, 0.0514575653, 0.1074065790, 0.6302613616) \n" +
1156                    "             * (tgt.rgb * tgt.rgb), forward);\n" +
1157                    "  lab.x = clamp(pow(lab.x, v_tweak.w) * v_lightFix * v_tweak.x + v_color.x - 1.0, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
1158                    "  lab.yz = clamp((lab.yz * v_tweak.yz + v_color.yz) * 1.5, -1.0, 1.0);\n" +
1159                    "  lab = mat3(1.0, 1.0, 1.0, +0.3963377774, -0.1055613458, -0.0894841775, +0.2158037573, -0.0638541728, -1.2914855480) * lab;\n" +
1160                    "  gl_FragColor = vec4(sqrt(clamp(" +
1161                    "                 mat3(+4.0767245293, -1.2681437731, -0.0041119885, -3.3072168827, +2.6093323231, -0.7034763098, +0.2307590544, -0.3411344290, +1.7068625689) *\n" +
1162                    "                 (lab * lab * lab)," +
1163                    "                 0.0, 1.0)), v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
1164                    "}";
1165
1166    /**
1167     * Takes a batch color in CIE LAB format (but ranging from 0 to 1 instead of its normal larger range).
1168     * Adapted from <a href="https://www.shadertoy.com/view/lsdGzN">This ShaderToy by nmz</a>.
1169     */
1170    public static String fragmentShaderCielab =
1171            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
1172            "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
1173            "precision mediump float;\n" +
1174            "#else\n" +
1175            "#define LOWP \n" +
1176            "#endif\n" +
1177            "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
1178            "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
1179            "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
1180            "const vec3 forward = vec3(1.0 / 3.0);\n" +
1181            "const vec3 sRGBFrom = vec3(2.4);\n" +
1182            "const vec3 sRGBThresholdFrom = vec3(0.04045);\n" +
1183            "const vec3 sRGBTo = vec3(1.0 / 2.4);\n" +
1184            "const vec3 sRGBThresholdTo = vec3(0.0031308);\n" +
1185            "const vec3 epsilon = vec3(0.00885645);\n" +
1186            "vec3 linear(vec3 t){ return mix(pow((t + 0.055) * (1.0 / 1.055), sRGBFrom), t * (1.0/12.92), step(t, sRGBThresholdFrom)); }\n" +
1187            "vec3 sRGB(vec3 t){ return mix(1.055 * pow(t, sRGBTo) - 0.055, 12.92*t, step(t, sRGBThresholdTo)); }\n" +
1188            "float xyzF(float t){ return mix(pow(t,1./3.), 7.787037 * t + 0.139731, step(t, 0.00885645)); }\n" +
1189            "vec3 xyzF(vec3 t){ return mix(pow(t, forward), 7.787037 * t + 0.139731, step(t, epsilon)); }\n" +
1190            "float xyzR(float t){ return mix(t*t*t , 0.1284185 * (t - 0.139731), step(t, 0.20689655)); }\n" +
1191            "vec3 rgb2lab(vec3 c)\n" +
1192            "{\n" +
1193            "    c *= mat3(0.4124, 0.3576, 0.1805,\n" +
1194            "              0.2126, 0.7152, 0.0722,\n" +
1195            "              0.0193, 0.1192, 0.9505);\n" +
1196            "    c = xyzF(c);\n" +
1197            "    vec3 lab = vec3(max(0.,1.16*c.y - 0.16), (c.x - c.y) * 5.0, (c.y - c.z) * 2.0); \n" +
1198            "    return lab;\n" +
1199//            "    return vec3(lab.x, length(vec2(lab.y,lab.z)), atan(lab.z, lab.y));\n" +
1200            "}\n" +
1201            "vec3 lab2rgb(vec3 c)\n" +
1202            "{\n" +
1203//            "    c = vec3(c.x, cos(c.z) * c.y, sin(c.z) * c.y);\n" +
1204            "    float lg = 1./1.16*(c.x + 0.16);\n" +
1205            "    vec3 xyz = vec3(xyzR(lg + c.y * 0.2),\n" +
1206            "                    xyzR(lg),\n" +
1207            "                    xyzR(lg - c.z * 0.5));\n" +
1208            "    vec3 rgb = xyz*mat3( 3.2406, -1.5372,-0.4986,\n" +
1209            "                        -0.9689,  1.8758, 0.0415,\n" +
1210            "                         0.0557, -0.2040, 1.0570);\n" +
1211            "    return rgb;\n" +
